results.name: Distances between successive ones in A051023, the middle column of rule-30 1-D cellular automaton, when started from a lone 1 cell.
comment: First differences of A327984, which gives indices of ones in A051023.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..100000
example: The evolution of one-dimensional cellular automaton rule 30 proceeds as follows, when started from a single alive (1) cell:

When noting up the distances between successive 1's in its central column (indicated here with parentheses), we obtain 1-0 (as the first 0 is on row 0, and the second is on row 1), 3-1, 4-3, 5-4, 8-5, 9-8, 13-9, ..., that is, the first terms on this sequence: 1, 2, 1, 1, 3, 1, 4, ...
program: A327981list(up_to) = { my(v=vector(up_to), s=1, n=0, on=n, k=0); while(k<up_to, n++; s = A269160(s); if((s>>n)%2, k++; v[k] = (n-on); on=n)); (v); }
